Using Dynamic TOPMODEL

Source: ../vignettes/dynatop.Rmd
dynatop.Rmd

The purpose of this vignette is to provide an outline of the steps needed to perform a Dynamic TOPMODEL simualtion and introduce the formats of the data input and returned.

The data used in this example comes from Brompton and is contained within the package and can be loaded with

devtools::load_all()
#> Loading dynatop
#> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'xts':
#>   method     from
#>   as.zoo.xts zoo
#> Loading required package: xts
#> Loading required package: zoo
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'zoo'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     as.Date, as.Date.numeric
## library(dynatop)
data("brompton")

which returns the following variables

names(brompton)
#> [1] "model" "rain"  "pet"   "qobs"

In the following # The model structure A dynamic TOPMODEL is described in a list object. The list has the following elements

names(brompton$model)
#> [1] "hru"   "param" "Wex"   "Wsat"  "Fex"   "Fsat"

which are described in Table <>. The [dynatop_gis]{http://bbc.co.uk} package can be used for constructing models and contains further details.

Checking the model

The structure of the model can be tested:

check_model(brompton$model)
#> Error in check_model(brompton$model): Saturated flow redistribution fractions sum to greater then 1 for HRUs: 101

In this case we can see three warning messages. The two warnings relate to the redistrubution of the flows from the <> hru. In both case sum of the fractions describing the destination of the flows is greater then 1, meaning that flow is artificually generated during the redistrbution. This can be checked manually by

model <- brompton$model
current_total_frac_sat <- colSums( rbind(model$Wsat,model$Fsat) )
current_total_frac_ex <- colSums( rbind(model$Wex,model$Fex) )

We can readily fix this:

model$Wsat[,'101'] <- model$Wsat[,'101']/current_total_frac_sat['101']
model$Fsat[,'101'] <- model$Fsat[,'101']/current_total_frac_sat['101']
model$Wex[,'101'] <- model$Wex[,'101']/current_total_frac_ex['101']
model$Fex[,'101'] <- model$Fex[,'101']/current_total_frac_ex['101']

and repeat the check:

check_model(model)
#> NULL

Altering parameters

The parmeter values are stored in the parameter vector model$parameters. Each parameter value has a unique name. In the current model the parameters are all set to their default values:

print(model$param)
#> srz_max_default   srz_0_default   ln_t0_default       m_default 
#>           0.050           0.990          19.000           0.004 
#>      td_default     tex_default 
#>          20.000         100.000

The relationship between the parameters and the HRUs are given in the columns of the HRU table e.g.

## unsaturated zone time constant
print( model$hru[,c('id','type','td')])
#>    id      type         td
#> 1   1   channel td_default
#> 2 101 hillslope td_default
#> 3 102 hillslope td_default
#> 4 103 hillslope td_default

As in the above (where the unsaturated zone time constant is specified for the channel HRU) there is no danger in specifying parameters not needed by the HRU type since these are ignored.

Altering parameter values requires changing there values in the parameter vector. For this catchment all HRU have the same parameter values. This could be altered by changing parameter names in the HRU table and adding these parameters to the parameter vector.

In this case we change the parameter vectors to me more representative of the catchment

model$param[c("srz_max_default","srz_0_default","ln_t0_default",
              "m_default","td_default","tex_default")] <-
    c(0.1,0.98,1.15,0.0044,33,0.2)

Preparing input data

The input to the model is expected to take the form of an xts object with constant time step whose column names are found in the â€˜precipâ€™ and â€˜peâ€™ columns of the HRU table in the model. Helpful functions for creating and manipulating obects can be found [here]{http://rstudio-pubs-static.s3.amazonaws.com/288218_117e183e74964557a5da4fc5902fc671.html}

The precipitation and potential evapotranspiration (PET) inputs for Brompton are contained the and variables. However while the PET input comes on a 15 minute time step

head(brompton$pet)
#>                     pet
#> 2012-01-01 00:00:00   0
#> 2012-01-01 00:15:00   0
#> 2012-01-01 00:30:00   0
#> 2012-01-01 00:45:00   0
#> 2012-01-01 01:00:00   0
#> 2012-01-01 01:15:00   0

the precipitation is on a courser hourly timestp

head(brompton$rain)
#> Warning: timezone of object (GMT) is different than current timezone ().
#>                     rain
#> 2012-09-01 00:00:00    0
#> 2012-09-01 01:00:00    0
#> 2012-09-01 02:00:00    0
#> 2012-09-01 03:00:00    0
#> 2012-09-01 04:00:00    0
#> 2012-09-01 05:00:00    0

The function can be used to alter the rainfall to the correct time step

rain <- resample_xts(brompton$rain, dt = 15/60)
#> Warning in resample_xts(brompton$rain, dt = 15/60): Irregularly spaced time
#> series supplied to resample_xts - proceding with modal timestep, results
#> are questionable

These series can then be merged, to give single xts object

obs <- merge(rain,brompton$pet,all=c(TRUE,FALSE))
obs <- merge(obs,brompton$qobs,all=c(TRUE,FALSE))

Letâ€™s now check this observed data

check_obs(obs, unique( unlist(model$hru[,c("precip_input","pet_input")]) ))
#> Error in check_obs(obs, unique(unlist(model$hru[, c("precip_input", "pet_input")]))): There are non finite values in the required time series

The check fails with a warning since there are non-finite values in the data. This requires more detailed investigation but as a simple fix

## replace all non finite values with 0
obs[!is.finite(obs)] <- 0
check_obs(obs, unique( unlist(model$hru[,c("precip_input","pet_input")]) ))
#> $step
#> [1] 0.25
#> 
#> $n_sub_step
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $sub_step
#> [1] 0.25

From the return of check_obs we can see the time step of the data and default number fo sub time steps used in the model evaluation which is discussed later.

Running dynamic TOPMODEL

The model can be run with the data using the dyantop command. For a event in November 2012 the model can be run with the command

## select the event period
event_period <- "2012-11-23 12:00::2012-12-01"
## recharge rate for initialisation
initial_recharge <- as.numeric(obs["2012-11-23 12:00",'qobs'])
## running the model
sim_1 <- dynatop(model,obs[event_period,],initial_recharge)
#> Running Dynamic TOPMODEL using 3 hillslope units and 1 channel units

The returned object from dynatop is a list with two elements

names(sim_1)
#> [1] "model"         "channel_input"
names(sim_1$model)
#> [1] "hru"    "param"  "Wex"    "Wsat"   "Fex"    "Fsat"   "states"
head(sim_1$channel_input)
#> Warning: timezone of object (GMT) is different than current timezone ().
#>                               1
#> 2012-11-23 12:00:00 0.007918407
#> 2012-11-23 12:15:00 0.007991802
#> 2012-11-23 12:30:00 0.008064530
#> 2012-11-23 12:45:00 0.008136624
#> 2012-11-23 13:00:00 0.008208116
#> 2012-11-23 13:15:00 0.008279035

which are an xts object of the flows to the channel HRUs at each time step and the model passed to the call augmented with the final states of the simulation.

In the above simulation the model was initialised using the flow at the start of the event and used the default timestep, which is the time step of the input data. Sub stepping, that is using a finer mueric timestep then the data can improve the stability and quality of the simulations. The <> parameter of the dynatop function can be used to impliment this. For example

sim_2 <- dynatop(model,obs[event_period,],initial_recharge,sim_time_step=5/60)
#> Running Dynamic TOPMODEL using 3 hillslope units and 1 channel units

performs the same simulation with a 5 minute time step.

The output states of a simulation can be used to initialise the a subsequent simulation. We note in doing this that no checks are made of the simulation times periods or of the timesteps used. For example

sim_3 <- dynatop(sim_1$model,obs[event_period,],sim_time_step=5/60,use_states=TRUE)
#> Running Dynamic TOPMODEL using 3 hillslope units and 1 channel units

The effects of the different implimentations can be seem in the following graph. Note that the descrepancy between the simulations and observed data is due in part to the absense of any channel routing.

out <- merge( merge( merge(obs,sim_1$channel_input),
                    sim_2$channel_input),
             sim_3$channel_input)
names(out) <- c(names(obs),'sim_1','sim_2','sim_3')
plot(out[,c('qobs','sim_1','sim_2','sim_3')])
